query: Can I get Universal Credit while I'm studying at university?

- you live with your partner and they're eligible for Universal Credit
- you're responsible for a child, either as a single person or as a couple
- you've reached State Pension age and live with a partner who is below State Pension age
- you've received a Migration Notice letter telling you to move to Universal Credit

Additionally, you may be able to claim if you are studying part-time or doing a course for which no student loan or finance is available. 
It's recommended to check the guidance about claiming Universal Credit as a student for more information.
(Source: gov.uk/universal-credit | Part: Eligibility | Updated: 2024-10-17T10:58:14+01:00)

query: What is the benefit cap and how does it affect Universal Credit?
reference_response:
The benefit cap is a limit on the total amount of benefit you can get, according to the GOV.UK page on benefit cap (updated 2024-10-21). It applies to most people aged 16 or over who have not reached State Pension age.

The benefit cap affects several benefits, including Universal Credit, as stated on the GOV.UK page on benefits affected by the cap (updated 2024-10-21). However, if you're claiming Universal Credit, the benefit cap might not start for 9 months, depending on your earnings, as explained on the GOV.UK page on when the benefit cap affects your Universal Credit payments (updated 2024-10-21).

To be eligible for the 9-month "grace period," you must meet certain conditions, including earning less than £846 a month and having earned at least the same amount in each of the 12 months before your earnings went down or you stopped working. You can find more information about the grace period and how it works on the GOV.UK page on when the benefit cap affects your Universal Credit payments (updated 2024-10-21).

It's also important to note that you might not be affected by the benefit cap if you or your partner get Universal Credit because of a disability or health condition, or if you care for someone with a disability, as stated on the GOV.UK page on when you're not affected by the cap (updated 2024-10-21). Additionally, if you and your partner earn £846 or more a month combined, you will not be affected by the cap.

If you're affected by the benefit cap, your Universal Credit payment will be reduced, as explained on the GOV.UK page on what you'll get from Universal Credit (updated 2024-10-17). However, after the 9-month grace period ends, the amount of Universal Credit you get will usually go down, unless your circumstances change and you're no longer affected by the benefit cap.

query: Who is eligible for Housing Benefit?
reference_response:
You can get Housing Benefit if you're unemployed, on a low income, or claiming benefits. However, you can only make a new claim for Housing Benefit if you've reached State Pension age or you're in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing. (Source: gov.uk/housing-benefit | Part: Eligibility)

To be eligible, you must also meet certain conditions. You're not eligible if:

* your savings are over £16,000 (unless you get Guarantee Credit of Pension Credit)
* you're paying a mortgage on your own home
* you live in the home of a close relative
* you're already claiming Universal Credit (unless you're in temporary or supported housing)
* you live with your partner and they're already claiming Housing Benefit
* you're a full-time student
* you're residing in the UK as a European Economic Area (EEA) jobseeker
* you're an asylum seeker or sponsored to be in the UK
* you're subject to immigration control and your granted leave states that you cannot claim public funds
* you're a Crown Tenant

You can use a benefits calculator to check if you can get Housing Benefit before you apply. (Source: gov.uk/housing-benefit | Part: Eligibility)

query: Can I get Housing Benefit if I'm over State Pension age?

If you're over State Pension age and live with your partner, you can make a new claim for Housing Benefit if:
- you and your partner have both reached State Pension age, 
- one of you has reached State Pension age and started claiming Pension Credit (for you as a couple) before 15 May 2019, or 
- you’re in supported, sheltered or temporary housing.

It's also stated that if you're over State Pension age and have an existing claim, your existing claim will not be affected if, before 15 May 2019, you were getting Housing Benefit and had reached State Pension age. 

To confirm your eligibility, you can use a benefits calculator or contact your local council. (Source: gov.uk/housing-benefit, updated 2024-10-17)

query: How is the amount of Housing Benefit calculated?
reference_response:
The amount of Housing Benefit you can get depends on several factors. 

If you rent from a council or social housing, your Housing Benefit is calculated based on your 'eligible rent', which is your actual rent plus any service charges you pay, but not things like heating or water costs. However, if you have a spare bedroom, your Housing Benefit could be reduced by 14% for one spare bedroom or 25% for two or more spare bedrooms (as stated on gov.uk/housing-benefit, updated 2024-10-17).

For private renters, your eligible rent amount is either your Local Housing Allowance (LHA) rate or your actual rent, whichever is lower. The LHA rate is based on where you live and your household size (gov.uk/housing-benefit, updated 2024-10-17).

In both cases, your household income, including benefits, pensions, and savings (over £6,000), and your circumstances, such as age or disability, are also taken into account when calculating your Housing Benefit (gov.uk/housing-benefit, updated 2024-10-17).

It's also important to note that the benefit cap may apply, which limits the total amount of benefit you can get. The benefit cap amounts vary depending on whether you live inside or outside Greater London, and your family situation (gov.uk/benefit-cap, updated 2024-10-21).

To get a more accurate estimate of your Housing Benefit, you can use a benefits calculator or contact your local council for more information.

query: What is the spare bedroom tax and how does it affect Housing Benefit?
reference_response:
The spare bedroom tax is a reduction in Housing Benefit for people who live in council or social housing and have a spare bedroom. (Source: gov.uk/housing-benefit | Part: What you'll get)

The reduction is:
- 14% of the 'eligible rent' for 1 spare bedroom
- 25% of the 'eligible rent' for 2 or more spare bedrooms

For example, if your eligible rent is £100 per week and you have 1 spare bedroom, your eligible rent would be reduced by 14% to £86 per week. Your Housing Benefit would then be calculated using the reduced figure of £86 per week.

However, there are some exceptions. You can have a spare bedroom for certain situations, such as for an approved foster carer or for an overnight carer. Additionally, rooms used by students or members of the armed forces who are away and intend to return home will not be counted as 'spare'. (Source: gov.uk/housing-benefit | Part: What you'll get)

query: Can I get Housing Benefit if I rent from a private landlord?

I recommend checking the GOV.UK website or contacting your local council for more information on how to claim and what evidence you need to provide.

query: How do I apply for council housing?
reference_response:
To apply for council housing, you'll need to contact your local council. You can apply if you're 18 or over (some councils let you apply if you're 16 or over). You may be able to apply even if you don't live in the area. 

You'll usually have to join a waiting list, and the council will decide who gets offered housing based on a 'points' or 'banding' system. This system is based on housing need, so you're more likely to be offered housing if you're homeless, live in cramped conditions, or have a medical condition made worse by your current home.

You can find more information on the application process on the GOV.UK website, specifically on the page about council housing (gov.uk/council-housing). query: What is the Right to Buy scheme?
reference_response:

To be eligible, you must meet certain criteria, including:

* The property must be your only or main home
* It must be self-contained
* You must be a secure tenant
* You must have had a public sector landlord (such as a council, housing association, or NHS trust) for at least 3 years (it doesn't have to be 3 years in a row)

If you're eligible, you can apply to buy your council home at a discount, which is based on the type of property, its value, where you live, and how long you've been a tenant with a public sector landlord. (Source: gov.uk/right-to-buy-buying-your-council-home, Part: Discounts)

You can find more information and get help with your application from your landlord, the Right to Buy summary booklet, the Right to Buy guidance, Money Helper, Citizens Advice, or your local Law Centre. (Source: gov.uk/right-to-buy-buying-your-council-home, Part: Help and advice)

query: Do students have to pay council tax?
reference_response:

To count as a full-time student, your course must last at least 1 year and involve at least 21 hours of study per week. If you're under 20 and studying for a qualification up to A level, your course must last at least 3 months and involve at least 12 hours of study per week.

However, if there's someone in your household who's not a full-time student, you might still get a discount on your Council Tax bill. You're considered 'disregarded' if you're a full-time student, and your household might get a 25% or 50% discount depending on the circumstances.

It's essential to contact your local council to apply for a discount or exemption, even if you think you're disregarded. They will help you determine the best course of action. query: What is Personal Independence Payment (PIP)?
reference_response:
Personal Independence Payment (PIP) is a benefit that can help with extra living costs if you have a long-term physical or mental health condition or disability, and you have difficulty doing certain everyday tasks or getting around because of your condition. (Source: gov.uk/pip, Part: What PIP is for)

PIP has two parts: a daily living part, which helps with everyday tasks like preparing food, eating and drinking, and managing your medicines, and a mobility part, which helps with getting around. The amount you get depends on how difficult you find these tasks. (Source: gov.uk/pip, Part: What PIP is for and Part: How much you’ll get)

You can get PIP even if you're working, have savings, or are getting most other benefits. (Source: gov.uk/pip, Part: What PIP is for)

query: What's the difference between PIP and DLA?
reference_response:
The main difference between Personal Independence Payment (PIP) and Disability Living Allowance (DLA) is the age of the person claiming the benefit. 

According to the context from GOV.UK (gov.uk/pip and gov.uk/disability-living-allowance-children), DLA is for children under 16, while PIP is for people aged 16 or over. 

When a child turns 16, they will need to apply for PIP instead of DLA. You can find more information about this on the GOV.UK page about Disability Living Allowance for children (gov.uk/disability-living-allowance-children). 

Additionally, DLA is being replaced by PIP for most adults, but some people, such as those born on or before 8 April 1948, will keep getting DLA. You can read more about PIP on the GOV.UK page about Personal Independence Payment (gov.uk/pip).

query: How do I apply for Attendance Allowance?
reference_response:
To apply for Attendance Allowance, you can either apply online or by post. 

If you want to apply online, you'll need your National Insurance number, address and contact details, details of your disability or health condition, and details of your GP surgery or medical centre (gov.uk/attendance-allowance, Part: How to claim). 

If you prefer to apply by post, you can print and send the Attendance Allowance claim form or contact the helpline to request a claim form. The helpline number is 0800 731 0122, and it's available from Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm (gov.uk/attendance-allowance, Part: How to claim). 

You should send the completed form to: Freepost, DWP Attendance Allowance. Remember not to write anything except the freepost address on the envelope, and you won't need a postcode or a stamp.

If you're nearing the end of life, there's a different way to claim, and you might be able to get Attendance Allowance more quickly and at a higher rate (gov.uk/attendance-allowance, Part: Claiming Attendance Allowance if you’re nearing the end of life). 

Please note that if you live in Scotland, you'll need to apply for Pension Age Disability Payment instead of Attendance Allowance (gov.uk/attendance-allowance, Part: Overview). 

It's also important to check the eligibility criteria before applying, which includes being at State Pension age, having a disability or health condition that requires help with caring for yourself, and meeting the habitual residence requirements (gov.uk/attendance-allowance, Part: Eligibility).

query: What are the daily living and mobility components of PIP?
reference_response:
The daily living and mobility components of Personal Independence Payment (PIP) are two parts that make up the benefit. 

The daily living part is for people who need help with everyday tasks, such as:
- preparing food
- eating and drinking
- managing medicines or treatments
- washing and bathing
- using the toilet
- dressing and undressing
- reading
- managing money
- socialising and being around other people
- talking, listening and understanding

The mobility part is for people who need help with getting around, such as:
- working out a route and following it
- physically moving around
- leaving your home

You might get one or both parts, depending on your needs. The amount you get for each part depends on how difficult you find these tasks. (Source: gov.uk/pip, Part: What PIP is for)

query: How often is PIP reviewed?
